When spidering a web site, always wait between requests at least as long as the request took. So time how long it takes you to get each node, and then sleep for (1+x)*T + y where x >= 0 and y >= 0 and T is how many seconds the previous request took.

[g0n], [localtime://2006-04-29 17:30:00]
The ongoing occasional problem with node authors removing their node content, or replacing it with 'thanks guys' or something to that effect, has cropped up a couple of times this week. Sometimes when this happens, the original node content can be retrieved from [http://www.prlmnks.org] or (if the node has been edited by a janitor) the node history. Other times the content is not easily available and (I think) we're reliant on [gods] or [pmdev|devels] to restore the content. As a 'spit and loo roll' temporary solution to this, I've written a little script to get the content of each node as it is posted. The script runs every 15 minutes from cron, reads the node using the xml displaytype, and writes the output to a file in [http://g0n.net/perlmonks] (there are some dns oddities with the g0n domain - if you can't reach that url try [http://82.69.8.21/perlmonks]. It's limited to retrieving a max of 25 nodes at a time so that it doesn't place too much load on the server. It retrieves the node only once, at the time of posting (or up to 15 minutes later) and doesn't pick up any modifications, but that does at least mean that deleting the original node content won't affect the copy. If there are no objections I'll leave it running for the time being to see if it's useful.

[davido], [localtime://2005-12-16 00:35:21]
Perhaps we're reading that paragraph differently. When I read it, the as much as possible referrs to "echo what the original poster probably intended." It doesn't refer to "We tidy up..." In other words, it is trying to say that as we tidy up, we try to preserve the OP's layout intent as much as possible. It shouldn't be read as "We tidy up as much as possible." And by preserving the OP's layout intent, I mean that we should look at the source that the OP typed. Many times there are strong clues there: line breaks in what was typed, but that don't appear in what gets rendered because they lack the necessary HTML formatting to match the layout that was typed in. ...if that makes sense. I'm not sure I know how to phrase it more clearly. But I do seem to remember being the one who most recently touched that part of the documentation, and I can only attempt to clarify its intent here.

That said, it's my belief that the goal should be to touch as little as possible, and if practical, give the OP an opportunity to affect the change first. But if we're clearly dealing with a newbie who has dumped twenty lines of text all run together with no formatting at all, that's a good time to look at the post's source, and attempt to elevate it out of line noise type obscurity by placing the formatting that will cause the rendering to appear pretty close to how it was actually typed (which is usually pretty legible).

It's my feeling that if a post just needs a 'thing or two', it should probably be left alone. If it's an utter unreadable disaster, it's not beyond our jurisdiction to make it readable without altering its content or the OP's intent.
